comments.author: Timelord2067
comments.body: Quote from: PalermoMoon on August 10, 2022, 02:28:11 AMLoan Amount: 0.0015 btcLoan Purpose: PersonalLoan Repay Amount: 0.002 btcLoan Repay Date: August 12Type of Collateral: Tron or DogeBtc address: 3N8E1EpzwNh7fV6PZirHipBizWSpsqbGo5Curiously, Coinmarketcap is suggesting both DOGE and TRON are 0.00000297 at the moment.BTC 0.001 of each would be approx 335.  So, rule of thumb, 125% of amount borrowed/risk would be approx 421 of each you would be offering as collateral.

comments.body: Nicely executed. Borrowers: this is how collateral is used (if you trust the lender to send first, as was the case here). I would encourage one stipulation re: how is collateral managed if its value drops below loan value, or perhaps increases substantially.Hash of a comment I'm making, just not yet revealing .. af65d29... nevermind, I rest my case

comments.author: LoyceMobile
comments.body: Out of curiosity: why not use an instant exchange instead? Fixedfloat would have given you 0.0015 Bitcoin for 520 Doge. Then, 2 days from now, you can swap 0.002 Bitcoin back for about 650 Doge. Unless you expect Doge to drop more than 20% in 2 days, that would have been a better deal.

comments.author: RikandMorty1
comments.body: Quote from: LoyceMobile on August 10, 2022, 12:45:15 PMOut of curiosity: why not use an instant exchange instead? Fixedfloat would have given you 0.0015 Bitcoin for 520 Doge. Then, 2 days from now, you can swap 0.002 Bitcoin back for about 650 Doge. Unless you expect Doge to drop more than 20% in 2 days, that would have been a better deal.In addition to that the interest given in this trade is insanly high (32% for only 2 days).This whole thing is just weird..

comments.author: Timelord2067
comments.body: Quote from: condoras on August 10, 2022, 10:57:19 AMI can cover it if Timelord2067 doesn't want to.I went to bed after making the first post, so I missed doing the trade.  I probably would have stipulated 48 hours from when the funds were provided, QuoteJust for the record, you forgot to include transaction fees for 2 transactions that burden the borrower..I would assume the borrower and lender each covers their TX fees unless otherwise factored in, but given as RikandMorty1 points out:Quote from: RikandMorty1 on August 10, 2022, 12:53:54 PMIn addition to that the interest given in this trade is insanly high (32% for only 2 days).The repayment amount would cover any nominal TX fees in this instance.QuoteThis whole thing is just weird..It certainly is.
